title: 113_hr361
content: The Act may be cited as the "Alpine Lakes Wilderness Additions and Pratt and Middle Fork Snoqualmie Rivers Protection Act". It includes the expansion of the Alpine Lakes Wilderness. Designated as wilderness in the Mount Baker-Snoqualmie National Forest in Washington, approximately 21,493 acres within the Proposed Alpine Lakes Wilderness Additions Boundary are part of the National Wilderness Preservation System. Administered by the Secretary of Agriculture, the land follows the Wilderness Act, except for any valid existing rights. The Wilderness Act applies to the designated wilderness area in Mount Baker-Snoqualmie National Forest, allowing for military overflights and prevention of wildfires. The Wilderness Act allows for prevention of wildfires in designated wilderness areas by authorizing mechanical thinning of trees and underbrush, as well as the use of mechanized equipment for wildfire suppression. The Secretary of Agriculture must file a map and legal description of the designated wilderness land with the Committee on Natural Resources of the House of Representatives. The map and legal description of designated wilderness land must be filed with the House of Representatives and the Senate's Committee on Energy and Natural Resources. The filed documents have the same legal force as the Act, with the Secretary allowed to make minor corrections. The documents must be made available for public inspection at the Forest Service office. SEC. 3. WILD AND SCENIC RIVER DESIGNATIONS. Section 3(a) of the Wild and Scenic Rivers Act is amended to include the Middle Fork Snoqualmie River in Washington, with a 27.4-mile segment designated for administration by the Secretary of Agriculture in two classifications: a 6.4-mile wild river segment and a 21-mile segment. The Pratt River in Washington, located in the Mount Baker-Snoqualmie National Forest, is designated as a scenic river. The Secretary of Agriculture cannot acquire land within the designated Wild and Scenic River segments through condemnation without consent from the landowner. Private or non-Federal public property must have written consent to be included in the designated river boundaries. The Secretary of Agriculture cannot acquire land within the designated Wild and Scenic River segments through condemnation without consent from the landowner. Private or non-Federal public property must have written consent to be included in the designated river boundaries. SEC. 4. ADJACENT LAND MANAGEMENT. This Act does not establish a protective perimeter around designated areas or restrict activities outside those boundaries.
